title: Skin
text:
Skin is the layer of usually soft, flexible outer tissue covering the body of a <a href="vertebrate">vertebrate</a> animal, with three main functions: protection, regulation, and sensation.
Other <a href="cuticle">animal coverings</a>, such as the <a href="arthropod%20exoskeleton">arthropod exoskeleton</a>, have different <a href="cellular%20differentiation">developmental origin</a>, structure and <a href="chemical%20composition">chemical composition</a>. The adjective cutaneous means "of the skin" (from Latin "cutis" 'skin'). In <a href="mammal">mammal</a>s, the skin is an <a href="organ%20%28anatomy%29">organ</a> of the <a href="integumentary%20system">integumentary system</a> made up of multiple layers of <a href="ectodermal">ectodermal</a> <a href="tissue%20%28biology%29">tissue</a> and guards the underlying <a href="muscle">muscle</a>s, <a href="bone">bone</a>s, <a href="ligament">ligament</a>s, and <a href="internal%20organs">internal organs</a>. Skin of a different nature exists in <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a>s, <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s, and <a href="bird">bird</a>s. Skin (including cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues) plays crucial roles in formation, structure, and function of extraskeletal apparatus such as horns of bovids (e.g., cattle) and rhinos, cervids' antlers, giraffids' ossicones, armadillos' osteoderm, and <a href="os%20penis">os penis</a>/<a href="os%20clitoris">os clitoris</a>. 
All mammals have some hair on their skin, even <a href="marine%20mammal">marine mammal</a>s like <a href="whale">whale</a>s, <a href="dolphin">dolphin</a>s, and <a href="porpoise">porpoise</a>s that appear to be hairless.
The skin interfaces with the environment and is the first line of defense from external factors. For example, the skin plays a key role in protecting the <a href="human%20body">body</a> against <a href="pathogen">pathogen</a>s and excessive water loss. Its other functions are <a href="thermal%20insulation">insulation</a>, <a href="Thermoregulation">temperature regulation</a>, sensation, and the production of <a href="vitamin%20D">vitamin D</a> folates. Severely damaged skin may heal by forming <a href="scar">scar tissue</a>. This is sometimes discoloured and depigmented. The thickness of skin also varies from location to location on an organism. In humans, for example, the skin located under the eyes and around the eyelids is the thinnest skin on the body at 0.5 mm thick and is one of the first areas to show signs of aging such as "crows feet" and wrinkles. The skin on the palms and the soles of the feet is the thickest skin on the body as 4 mm thick. The speed and quality of wound healing in skin is promoted by the reception of <a href="estrogen">estrogen</a>.
<a href="Fur">Fur</a> is dense hair. Primarily, fur augments the insulation the skin provides but can also serve as a <a href="Secondary%20sex%20characteristic">secondary sexual characteristic</a> or as <a href="camouflage">camouflage</a>. On some animals, the skin is very hard and thick and can be processed to create <a href="leather">leather</a>. <a href="Reptile">Reptile</a>s and most <a href="fish">fish</a> have hard protective scales on their skin for protection, and <a href="bird">bird</a>s have hard <a href="feather">feather</a>s, all made of tough <a href="beta-keratin">beta-keratin</a>s. <a href="Amphibian">Amphibian</a> skin is not a strong barrier, especially regarding the passage of chemicals via skin, and is often subject to <a href="osmosis">osmosis</a> and diffusive forces. For example, a <a href="frog">frog</a> sitting in an <a href="anesthetic">anesthetic</a> solution would be sedated quickly as the chemical diffuses through its skin. <a href="Amphibian">Amphibian</a> skin plays key roles in everyday survival and their ability to exploit a wide range of habitats and ecological conditions.
Etymology.
The word skin originally only referred to dressed and tanned animal hide and the usual word for human skin was hide.
Skin is a borrowing from <a href="Old%20Norse">Old Norse</a> skinn "animal hide, fur", ultimately from the <a href="Proto-Indo-European">Proto-Indo-European</a> root *sek-, meaning "to cut" (probably a reference to the fact that in those times animal hide was commonly cut off to be used as garment).
Structure in humans and other mammals.
Mammalian skin is composed of two primary layers:
Epidermis.
The epidermis is composed of the outermost layers of the skin. It forms a protective barrier over the body's surface, responsible for keeping water in the body and preventing <a href="pathogens">pathogens</a> from entering, and is a stratified squamous <a href="epithelium">epithelium</a>, composed of <a href="cell%20division">proliferating</a> basal and <a href="cell%20differentiation">differentiated</a> suprabasal <a href="keratinocyte">keratinocyte</a>s.
<a href="Keratinocyte">Keratinocyte</a>s are the major <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a>, constituting 95% of the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a>, while <a href="Merkel%20cell">Merkel cell</a>s, <a href="melanocyte">melanocyte</a>s and <a href="Langerhans%20cell">Langerhans cell</a>s are also present. The <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> can be further subdivided into the following "strata" or layers (beginning with the outermost layer):
<a href="Keratinocyte">Keratinocyte</a>s in the <a href="stratum%20basale">stratum basale</a> proliferate through <a href="mitosis">mitosis</a> and the daughter <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> move up the strata changing shape and composition as they undergo multiple stages of <a href="cell%20differentiation">cell differentiation</a> to eventually become anucleated. During that process, <a href="keratinocyte">keratinocyte</a>s will become highly organized, forming <a href="cell%20junction">cellular junctions</a> (<a href="desmosomes">desmosomes</a>) between each other and secreting <a href="keratin">keratin</a> <a href="proteins">proteins</a> and <a href="lipids">lipids</a> which contribute to the formation of an <a href="extracellular%20matrix">extracellular matrix</a> and provide mechanical <a href="strength%20of%20materials">strength</a> to the skin. <a href="Keratinocyte">Keratinocyte</a>s from the <a href="stratum%20corneum">stratum corneum</a> are eventually shed from the surface (<a href="desquamation">desquamation</a>).
The <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> contains no <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s, and <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> in the deepest layers are nourished by diffusion from <a href="blood">blood</a> <a href="capillaries">capillaries</a> extending to the upper layers of the <a href="dermis">dermis</a>.
Basement membrane.
The <a href="epidermis">epidermis</a> and <a href="dermis">dermis</a> are separated by a thin sheet of <a href="fibers">fibers</a> called the <a href="basement%20membrane">basement membrane</a>, which is made through the action of both <a href="tissue%20%28biology%29">tissues</a>.
The basement membrane controls the traffic of the <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> and <a href="molecules">molecules</a> between the dermis and epidermis but also serves, through the binding of a variety of <a href="cytokine">cytokine</a>s and <a href="growth%20factors">growth factors</a>, as a reservoir for their controlled release during <a href="physiological">physiological</a> remodeling or repair processes.
Dermis.
The dermis is the layer of skin beneath the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> that consists of <a href="connective%20tissue">connective tissue</a> and cushions the body from <a href="stress%20%28biology%29">stress</a> and strain. The <a href="dermis">dermis</a> provides tensile <a href="strength%20of%20materials">strength</a> and <a href="elasticity%20%28physics%29">elasticity</a> to the skin through an <a href="extracellular%20matrix">extracellular matrix</a> composed of <a href="collagen%20fibrils">collagen fibrils</a>, <a href="microfibrils">microfibrils</a>, and <a href="elastic%20fibers">elastic fibers</a>, embedded in <a href="hyaluronan">hyaluronan</a> and <a href="proteoglycan">proteoglycan</a>s. Skin proteoglycans are varied and have very specific locations. For example, <a href="hyaluronan">hyaluronan</a>, <a href="versican">versican</a> and <a href="decorin">decorin</a> are present throughout the dermis and <a href="epidermis">epidermis</a> <a href="extracellular%20matrix">extracellular matrix</a>, whereas <a href="biglycan">biglycan</a> and <a href="perlecan">perlecan</a> are only found in the epidermis.
It harbors many <a href="mechanoreceptor">mechanoreceptor</a>s (nerve endings) that provide the sense of <a href="touch">touch</a> and heat through <a href="nociceptor">nociceptor</a>s and <a href="thermoreceptor">thermoreceptor</a>s. It also contains the <a href="hair%20follicle">hair follicle</a>s, <a href="sweat%20gland">sweat gland</a>s, <a href="sebaceous%20gland">sebaceous gland</a>s, <a href="apocrine%20glands">apocrine glands</a>, <a href="lymphatic%20vessel">lymphatic vessel</a>s and <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s. The <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s in the <a href="dermis">dermis</a> provide nourishment and waste removal from its own <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> as well as for the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a>.
Dermis and subcutaneous tissues are thought to contain germinative cells involved in formation of horns, osteoderm, and other extra-skeletal apparatus in mammals. 
The <a href="dermis">dermis</a> is tightly connected to the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> through a <a href="basement%20membrane">basement membrane</a> and is structurally divided into two areas: a superficial area adjacent to the epidermis, called the "papillary region", and a deep thicker area known as the "reticular region".
Papillary region.
The papillary region is composed of loose <a href="areolar%20connective%20tissue">areolar connective tissue</a>. This is named for its fingerlike projections called "papillae" that extend toward the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a>. The papillae provide the <a href="dermis">dermis</a> with a "bumpy" surface that interdigitates with the epidermis, strengthening the connection between the two layers of skin.
Reticular region.
The reticular region lies deep in the papillary region and is usually much thicker. It is composed of dense irregular <a href="connective%20tissue">connective tissue</a> and receives its name from the dense concentration of <a href="collagen">collagen</a>ous, <a href="Elastic%20fibers">elastic</a>, and <a href="Reticular%20fiber">reticular</a> fibers that weave throughout it. These <a href="protein">protein</a> fibers give the <a href="dermis">dermis</a> its properties of <a href="strength%20of%20materials">strength</a>, <a href="extensibility">extensibility</a>, and <a href="elasticity%20%28physics%29">elasticity</a>.
Also located within the reticular region are the <a href="roots%20of%20the%20hair">roots of the hair</a>, <a href="sweat%20gland">sweat gland</a>s, <a href="sebaceous%20gland">sebaceous gland</a>s, <a href="Cutaneous%20receptor">receptors</a>, <a href="nail%20%28anatomy%29">nails</a>, and <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s.
Subcutaneous tissue.
The <a href="subcutaneous%20tissue">subcutaneous tissue</a> (also hypodermis) is not part of the skin, and lies below the <a href="dermis">dermis</a>. Its purpose is to attach the skin to underlying <a href="bone">bone</a> and <a href="muscle">muscle</a> as well as supplying it with <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s and <a href="nerve">nerve</a>s. It consists of loose <a href="connective%20tissue">connective tissue</a> and <a href="elastin">elastin</a>. The main <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cell</a> types are <a href="fibroblast">fibroblast</a>s, <a href="macrophage">macrophage</a>s and <a href="adipocyte">adipocyte</a>s (the subcutaneous tissue contains 50% of <a href="body%20fat">body fat</a>). <a href="Fat">Fat</a> serves as padding and insulation for the body.
<a href="Microorganisms">Microorganisms</a> like "<a href="Staphylococcus">Staphylococcus</a> epidermidis" colonize the skin surface. The density of <a href="skin%20flora">skin flora</a> depends on region of the skin. The disinfected skin surface gets recolonized from <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a> residing in the deeper areas of the <a href="hair%20follicle">hair follicle</a>, <a href="gastrointestinal%20tract">gut</a> and <a href="urogenital">urogenital</a> openings.
Structure in fish, amphibians, birds, and reptiles.
Fish.
The epidermis of <a href="fish">fish</a> and of most <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a>s consists entirely of live <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a>, with only minimal quantities of <a href="keratin">keratin</a> in the cells of the superficial layer. It is generally permeable, and in the case of many <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a>, may actually be a major respiratory organ. The <a href="dermis">dermis</a> of <a href="bony%20fish">bony fish</a> typically contains relatively little of the <a href="connective%20tissue">connective tissue</a> found in <a href="tetrapod">tetrapod</a>s. Instead, in most species, it is largely replaced by solid, protective bony <a href="scale%20%28zoology%29">scales</a>. Apart from some particularly large dermal bones that form parts of the <a href="skull">skull</a>, these <a href="scale%20%28zoology%29">scales</a> are lost in <a href="tetrapods">tetrapods</a>, although many <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s do have <a href="scale%20%28zoology%29">scales</a> of a different kind, as do <a href="pangolin">pangolin</a>s. <a href="Cartilaginous%20fish">Cartilaginous fish</a> have numerous tooth-like <a href="Dermal%20denticle">denticles</a> embedded in their skin, in place of true <a href="scale%20%28zoology%29">scales</a>.
<a href="Sweat%20gland">Sweat gland</a>s and <a href="sebaceous%20gland">sebaceous gland</a>s are both unique to <a href="mammals">mammals</a>, but other types of skin gland are found in other <a href="vertebrates">vertebrates</a>. <a href="Fish">Fish</a> typically have a numerous individual <a href="mucus">mucus</a>-secreting skin <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> that aid in insulation and protection, but may also have <a href="poison">poison</a> <a href="glands">glands</a>, <a href="photophore">photophore</a>s, or <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> that produce a more watery, <a href="serous">serous</a> fluid. In <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a>, the <a href="mucus">mucus</a> <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> are gathered together to form sac-like <a href="glands">glands</a>. Most living <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a> also possess "granular <a href="glands">glands</a>" in the skin, that secrete irritating or toxic compounds.
Although <a href="melanin">melanin</a> is found in the skin of many species, in the <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s, the <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a>, and <a href="fish">fish</a>, the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> is often relatively colorless. Instead, the color of the skin is largely due to <a href="chromatophore">chromatophore</a>s in the <a href="dermis">dermis</a>, which, in addition to melanin, may contain <a href="guanine">guanine</a> or <a href="carotenoid">carotenoid</a> <a href="pigments">pigments</a>. Many species, such as <a href="chameleon">chameleon</a>s and <a href="flounder">flounder</a>s may be able to change the color of their skin by adjusting the relative size of their <a href="chromatophores">chromatophores</a>.
Amphibians.
Overview.
Amphibians possess two types of <a href="gland">gland</a>s, <a href="Mucous%20gland">mucous</a> and granular (serous). Both of these glands are part of the <a href="integument">integument</a> and thus considered <a href="cutaneous">cutaneous</a>. Mucous and granular glands are both divided into three different sections which all connect to structure the gland as a whole. The three individual parts of the gland are the duct, the intercalary region, and lastly the alveolar gland (sac). Structurally, the duct is derived via <a href="keratinocyte">keratinocyte</a>s and passes through to the surface of the <a href="Epidermis">epidermal</a> or outer skin layer thus allowing external secretions of the body. The gland alveolus is a sac shaped structure that is found on the bottom or base region of the granular gland. The cells in this sac specialize in secretion. Between the alveolar gland and the duct is the intercalary system which can be summed up as a transitional region connecting the duct to the grand alveolar beneath the epidermal skin layer. In general, granular glands are larger in size than the mucous glands, however mucous glands hold a much greater majority in overall number.
Granular glands.
Granular glands can be identified as <a href="venom">venom</a>ous and often differ in the type of toxin as well as the concentrations of secretions across various orders and species within the amphibians. They are located in clusters differing in concentration depending on <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a> taxa. The toxins can be fatal to most vertebrates or have no effect against others. These glands are alveolar meaning they structurally have little sacs in which venom is produced and held before it is secreted upon defensive behaviors.
Structurally, the ducts of the granular gland initially maintain a cylindrical shape. However, when the ducts become mature and full of fluid, the base of the ducts become swollen due to the pressure from the inside. This causes the epidermal layer to form a pit like opening on the surface of the duct in which the inner fluid will be secreted in an upwards fashion.
The intercalary region of granular glands is more developed and mature in comparison with mucous glands. This region resides as a ring of cells surrounding the basal portion of the duct which are argued to have an <a href="ectoderm">ectoderm</a>al muscular nature due to their influence over the lumen (space inside the tube) of the duct with dilation and constriction functions during secretions. The cells are found radially around the duct and provide a distinct attachment site for muscle fibers around the gland's body.
The gland alveolus is a sac that is divided into three specific regions/layers. The outer layer or tunica fibrosa is composed of densely packed connective-tissue which connects with fibers from the spongy intermediate layer where elastic fibers, as well as nerves, reside. The nerves send signals to the muscles as well as the epithelial layers. Lastly, the epithelium or tunica propria encloses the gland.
Mucous glands.
<a href="Mucous%20gland">Mucous gland</a>s are non-venomous and offer a different functionality for amphibians than granular. Mucous glands cover the entire surface area of the amphibian body and specialize in keeping the body lubricated. There are many other functions of the mucous glands such as controlling the pH, thermoregulation, adhesive properties to the environment, anti-predator behaviors (slimy to the grasp), chemical communication, even anti-bacterial/viral properties for protection against pathogens.
The ducts of the mucous gland appear as cylindrical vertical tubes that break through the epidermal layer to the surface of the skin. The cells lining the inside of the ducts are oriented with their longitudinal axis forming 90-degree angles surrounding the duct in a helical fashion.
Intercalary cells react identically to those of granular glands but on a smaller scale. Among the amphibians, there are taxa which contain a modified intercalary region (depending on the function of the glands), yet the majority share the same structure.
The alveolar or mucous glands are much more simple and only consist of an epithelium layer as well as connective tissue which forms a cover over the gland. This gland lacks a tunica propria and appears to have delicate and intricate fibers which pass over the gland's muscle and epithelial layers.
Birds and reptiles.
The <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> of <a href="bird">bird</a>s and <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s is closer to that of <a href="mammals">mammals</a>, with a layer of dead keratin-filled <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> at the surface, to help reduce water loss. A similar pattern is also seen in some of the more terrestrial <a href="amphibians">amphibians</a> such as <a href="toad">toad</a>s. However, in all of these animals there is no clear <a href="cell%20differentiation">differentiation</a> of the <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> into distinct layers, as occurs in <a href="human">human</a>s, with the change in <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cell</a> type being relatively gradual. The mammalian <a href="epidermis%20%28skin%29">epidermis</a> always possesses at least a <a href="stratum%20germinativum">stratum germinativum</a> and <a href="stratum%20corneum">stratum corneum</a>, but the other intermediate layers found in <a href="human">human</a>s are not always distinguishable.
<a href="Hair">Hair</a> is a distinctive feature of mammalian skin, while <a href="feather">feather</a>s are (at least among living species) similarly unique to <a href="bird">bird</a>s.
<a href="Bird">Bird</a>s and <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s have relatively few skin <a href="gland">gland</a>s, although there may be a few structures for specific purposes, such as <a href="pheromone">pheromone</a>-secreting <a href="cell%20%28biology%29">cells</a> in some <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s, or the <a href="uropygial%20gland">uropygial gland</a> of most birds.
Functions.
Skin performs the following functions:
Mechanics.
Skin is a soft tissue and exhibits key mechanical behaviors of these tissues. The most pronounced feature is the J-curve stress strain response, in which a region of large strain and minimal stress exists and corresponds to the microstructural straightening and reorientation of collagen fibrils. In some cases the intact skin is prestreched, like wetsuits around the diver's body, and in other cases the intact skin is under compression. Small circular holes punched on the skin may widen or close into ellipses, or shrink and remain circular, depending on preexisting stresses.
Ageing.
Tissue <a href="homeostasis">homeostasis</a> generally declines with age, in part because <a href="stem%20cell">stem</a>/progenitor cells fail to self-renew or <a href="cellular%20differentiation">differentiate</a>. In the skin of mice, <a href="mitochondrion">mitochondrial</a> <a href="oxidative%20stress">oxidative stress</a> can promote <a href="cellular%20senescence">cellular senescence</a> and <a href="ageing">aging</a> phenotypes. Ordinarily mitochondrial superoxide dismutase (<a href="SOD2">SOD2</a>) protects against oxidative stress. Using a mouse model of genetic SOD2 deficiency, it was shown that failure to express this important antioxidant enzyme in epidermal cells caused cellular senescence, nuclear <a href="DNA%20damage%20%28naturally%20occurring%29">DNA damage</a>, and irreversible arrest of proliferation of a fraction of <a href="keratinocyte">keratinocyte</a>s.
Skin aging is caused in part by <a href="TGF-%CE%B2">TGF-β</a>, which reduces the subcutaneous fat that gives skin a pleasant appearance and texture. <a href="TGF-%CE%B2">TGF-β</a> does this by blocking the conversion of <a href="dermal%20fibroblasts">dermal fibroblasts</a> into <a href="fat%20cells">fat cells</a>; with fewer fat cells underneath to provide support, the skin becomes saggy and wrinkled. Subcutaneous fat also produces <a href="cathelicidin">cathelicidin</a>, which is a <a href="peptide">peptide</a> that fights bacterial infections.
Society and culture.
The term "skin" may also refer to the covering of a small animal, such as a <a href="sheep">sheep</a>, <a href="goat">goat</a> (<a href="goatskin%20%28material%29">goatskin</a>), <a href="pig">pig</a>, snake (<a href="snakeskin">snakeskin</a>) etc. or the young of a large animal.
The term <a href="Hide%20%28skin%29">hides</a> or <a href="Rawhide%20%28material%29">rawhide</a> refers to the covering of a large adult animal such as a <a href="cow">cow</a>, <a href="American%20bison">buffalo</a>, <a href="horse">horse</a> etc.
Skins and <a href="Hide%20%28skin%29">hides</a> from the different animals are used for <a href="clothing">clothing</a>, bags and other <a href="consumer%20products">consumer products</a>, usually in the form of <a href="leather">leather</a>, but also as <a href="fur">fur</a>s.
Skin from <a href="sheep">sheep</a>, <a href="goat">goat</a> and <a href="cattle">cattle</a> was used to make <a href="parchment">parchment</a> for <a href="manuscript">manuscript</a>s.
Skin can also be cooked to make <a href="pork%20rind">pork rind</a> or <a href="pork%20rind">crackling</a>.
